instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMBUS_BATT_SCL: What is SMBUS_BATT_SCL? SMBUS_BATT_SCL is the clock line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED..
definitions.D7050: What is D7050? Diodes between SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL and ground, these data lines allow the battery to communicate with the battery charging chip and the SMC..
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.U5000: What is U5000? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in macbooks from 2013-2015.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.SMC_FAN_0_TACH: What is SMC_FAN_0_TACH? SMC_FAN_0_TACH is a signal that comes from the SMC that controls fan speed. Often when the fan is spinning too fast it is because the user has ripped off a resistor that this signal goes through before the signal reaches the fan while unplugging the fan..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short to ground on <SIGNAL>SMBUS_BATT_SCL</SIGNAL>
threads.message: The board has waterdamage in the battery connector area. It still boots to OS, but it's not detecting the battery. <SIGNAL>SMBUS_BATT_SCL</SIGNAL> measures 0.4 ohms to ground. <RESISTOR>R5381</RESISTOR> measures 2000 Ohms from the PP3v42 side. I already replaced <DIODE>D7050</DIODE>, but the short is still there. the only other termination points i can find in the schematic are on <CHIP>U5000</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>. Is there a way to tell if its <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> other than replacing it? or could the short be somewhere else still?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short to ground on <SIGNAL>SMBUS_BATT_SCL</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Replace ISL if short is still there can only be the SMC, I injected 3v into one of these once and the smc got a tiny bit warm just enough to evaporate a thin layer of alcohol slightly faster. I guess you could try that if you wanted to be 100%

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short to ground on <SIGNAL>SMBUS_BATT_SCL</SIGNAL>
threads.message: This is really only the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> or the SMC. One way to find out; remove! Obviously begin with the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short to ground on <SIGNAL>SMBUS_BATT_SCL</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Well, sometimes lucky rubber ducky, the machine recognises the battery again after replacing the ISL.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short to ground on <SIGNAL>SMBUS_BATT_SCL</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I am returning to this one for a less clear issue. After re-assembling the machine and final testing it turns out the machine is running throttled. Self-diagnostics of the machine give error PPF004, issues with the fan.
turning it to maximum using macs fan control shows that it is only running at 5700 rpm maximum. after replacing resistors <RESISTOR>R6060</RESISTOR> i am getting 6100 rpm max with a known good fan, only 100 rpm off what it is supposed to be. The machine is still running throttled.

When the fan is off <TRANSISTOR>Q6060</TRANSISTOR> measures
pin 1: 3.3 V
pin 2: 0v
pin 3: 0v

when hte fan is on full
pin 1: 3.3v
pin 2: 3,4v
pin 3: 5.05v

Resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>SMC_FAN_0_TACH</SIGNAL> is 103.4 Ohms

is there any way to check is this is the actual cause of the problem? and also any way to maybe artificially squeeze out a little more rpm is this if the problem? I suspect the problem is not with the actual rpm of the fan, but the measured rpm value, so maybe changing the reistance on one of the voltage divider resistors a little might fix this?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> short to ground on <SIGNAL>SMBUS_BATT_SCL</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Either bad SMC or crap under SMC.
